column1: The Three Stigmata of Palmer Eldritch
column9: As crazy as ever, and often tricky to follow the flips in and out of realities, but ultimately very inventive and enjoyable book.

column1: The Long Race to Glory: How the British Came to Rule the Cycling World
column9: Not much more than a timeline through British Cycling history, namechecking loads of people along the way. Not a huge amount of analysis.
column12: https://www.amazon.co.uk/s/ref=nb_sb_ss_c_2_12?url=search-alias%3Dstripbooks&field-keywords=The Long Race to Glory: How the British Came to Rule the Cycling World

column9: Fun. In digestible chunks. I liked the more serious writing more than the amusing throwaway stuff, but that was good too.

column1: The Hyperion Omnibus: Hyperion, The Fall of Hyperion
column9: Epic. Got into the characters, as their stories played out, though did find some if it all a bit impenetrable, but I think that tends to be par for the course with this kind of mammoth Sci-Fi. There was poetry too, which leaves me cold. Not enough to put me off.
column12: https://www.amazon.co.uk/s/ref=nb_sb_ss_c_2_12?url=search-alias%3Dstripbooks&field-keywords=The Hyperion Omnibus: Hyperion, The Fall of Hyperion

column1: The Woman who Went to Bed for a Year
column9: Simply written and direct style makes it easy to read, but with a subtle cutting edge to the satire. Bit of an abrubt ending.
column12: https://www.amazon.co.uk/s/ref=nb_sb_ss_c_2_12?url=search-alias%3Dstripbooks&field-keywords=The Woman who Went to Bed for a Year

column9: Loved the ideas throughout. Great descriptions of the future planet and creative imaginining about future lifeforms. Really enjoyed the language. The plot was nicely dramtic and all came together really enjoyably.
